All the domes will have plastic floors so no water is lost. Condensation forming on the ceilings will be drained into the water supply. So interesting video. Awesome! I take a slightly different view on the impact of the shuttle being man rated driving up the refurbishment costs. The MIT open course where series on the design of the shuttle highlighted the fact that because the shuttle was man rated no one was willing to go on the statistical probability that a part will reach its design life.  So, for example, if a part had a design life of 100 hours, and only was used for 10 hours per launch. They would still have to inspect that part even after only 10 hours of use because the shuttle was man rated. They could not afford to take that risk. The Falcon 9 that recently launched the crewed Dragon was a new rocket. I wonder what it will be like when they try to launch humans on the refurbished/reusable Falcon booster.

A frustum is the volume of a portion of a cone or pyramid. For example you cut the tip off a rocket cone for a parachute, or guidance equipment, you want to know the remaining volume. The frustum is the remaining volume. Another example, you have a curved bathtub that you want to know the exact volume of; the top is flat, the bottom it flat, the sides are curved, you could trace that curve through the floor of the tub to make a weird shaped cone thing; the tub water volume is the frustum of the weird shaped cone thing.

Also, and more important, frustum is the word you use to find the formula needed to calculate the volume in a problem involving a part of a cone. Because frankly the calculus needed to do it by other means is waaaaaaaaaaaaaay harder to learn than a simple reference word.

Comparing Falcon 9 refurbishment to the Space Shuttle isn't quite fair since the Space Shuttle was manned.  A better comparison will be to the Falcon 9 plus Dragon capsule.  Will the capsules be re-used?  Will NASA allow manned flights on used Falcon 9 boosters?  As mentioned, Space Shuttle refurbishment became overwrought, requiring almost 100x more man-hours than before the Challenger incident.  This is a typical government response after any incident.  A similar example is the U.S. nuclear power industry, which required ~10x more personnel after the Three Mile Island incident, per government regulations, with most simply pushing paper, fussing about things like calibration dates for steel rulers and probably adding little value.  True that the biggest cost and complexity was having to check and refurbish the thermal protection system on the Shuttle, which is much more area than a capsule.  Falcon 9 launches avoid this by returning the 1st-stage early, at a speed similar to the Space Shuttle solid rockets (jettison both a few minutes after launch), where thermal protection for re-entry isn't needed, and discarding the 2nd stage.  Thus, the main problem with the Shuttle was being closer to a Single-Stage-To-Orbit system.  Having the Shuttle mounted to the side where the tiles were struck by foam and ice made this a much worse problem (proved fatal).  SpaceX StarShip will also be a large re-entry vehicle, so may prove a similar refurbishment effort, depending upon the thermal protection it will use.

My dad worked at Lockheed Flight Test in the 80s and one of the things he worked on was vibration testing on the Space Shuttle. One of the checks they would do at NASA for the Space Shuttle was on the elevators at the back of the wings. They would strip off the heat shielding and check visually for any cracks forming. The guys at Lockheed had the idea of using vibration testing to check for cracks, checking the resonant frequency of the elevators in order to see if it had changed, if it changed the there were cracks and if it hadn’t changed then there were no cracks. I wonder what other innovations could’ve been used to bring down the cost of refurbishing the Shuttle.

While I do believe SpaceX is moving in the right direction to making getting to orbit much cheaper, the Falcon 9 is not there yet. When rockets can land, get a turnaround maintenance like jetliners, and launch again, we will hit a huge milestone (and even planes can be flown again right away after a simple refueling though that's not always recommended). SpaceX doesn't seem to be putting out much hype but the fanboys sure are. What they fail to mention is the performance hit the reusable Falcon 9 takes versus the expendable Falcon 9, a significant hit.

Elon Musk put it like this, his Falcon 9 costs around the same as a discounted 737 jetliner. So imagine if every time an airline flew passengers on one of their jets, that jet had to be trashed and the airline would have to buy a new jet. Air travel would be so expensive, only billionaires could afford to fly and it would be expensive for them. That doesn't happen though (most of the time thankfully), instead the airliner lands, it gets some maintenance, refueled, and ready to fly again.

We've been doing this with rockets since the beginning. It wasn't always imagined this way, I remember reading short sci-fi stories from the 40s and 50s assumed rockets would take off, fly in space, and just land. But during the Cold War, it was quicker, cheaper, and more expedient to just build rockets to be used once.

The reason that Space-x's rockets are much more reusable isn't necessarily because of Space-x's innovation (not trying to belittle space-x they do some amazing things and have some incredibly talented people working for them) but rather the conditions and context of the boosters and their flight as follows:
1. Engines - Space-x uses an open cycle engine, a simpler and cheaper, but less powerful engine than the Space Shuttle Main Engines (SSMEs).
2. Thermal protection - as discussed the boosters re enter at a much slower velocity than the orbiter and therefore do not require the thermal protection of the orbiter and the associated expense
3. The vehicle - the Space-x boosters are not really spacecraft, they don't have all the avionics, life support systems, and power generation systems that the orbiter had. I'm very curious to see Space-x's turnaround time and cost for turning around a booster, and presumably a capsule once they start flying humans.
4. Vehicle size - the orbiter was the largest spacecraft to ever fly, and that size had an effect on inspection and turnaround times and cost, Space-x's booster and capsule are so much smaller in comparison
5. Private vs Public - the STS (shuttle) program was an endeavor by the federal government and was subject to politics, components came with stipulations that they be built in districts of politicians who voted on the project, this is true of the SLS program and why it is so over budget and behind schedule and why congress doesn't want to kill it. Meanwhile Space-x is a private company, it can do it's business however it seems fit.
I really like what Space-x is doing, they are capturing the public's imagination and grabbing attention with science and engineering which is sorely needed in this day and age. I think Space-x will be able to reduce the cost and increase the frequency of spaceflight, but the exact same promises were made of the STS program back in the late 70's and early 80's and we got was a far cry from what was promised.
The other thing that you have to consider is that human rated rockets must have much higher safety ratings. Will SpaceX ever reuse its falcon 9s for more than 1 human rated mission.?

The reentry heating comes mainly from two sources, convective heating, the hot gas/air flow past the surface of body and chemical reactions, catalytic chemical recombination reactions /according to wikipedia/.

The space vehicle (shuttle) pushes and compresses the air in front of it due its high speed, and because of the thermodynamic equilibrium compressed gas gets hotter, in this case it gets so hot it even becomes plasma (if its ionized gas, and that seems to be the case) that's why there is the orange glow when the space shuttle (or any KSP rockets xD) does reentry.

So most people gets this wrong, that the "friction" heats up "object" at reentry!

No, its mostly the hot "air" around it that is being pushed and compressed (therefore it gets hot) and other chemical reactions between that hot air and the surface of the object (space shuttle, falcon booster, meteorites, etc).

A more useful comparison would be based on capacity. The shuttle could lift 7 astronauts and ~20 tons+ of cargo to the ISS comfortably. Cargo could be enclosed or open in the bay depending on what it was and how packed. Now crewed dragon will be hauling I think only 3 people to the ISS (because thats all NASA wants on it) but can of course haul seven. So a valid comparison would be between 1 shuttle flight and 1 crewed dragon PLUS 4 cargo dragon flights to achieve the same cargo. So now you are talking about "refurbishing" and/or "reusing" 5 dragon first stages, 1 crewed dragon capsule and 4 cargo dragon capsules (all of which have gone for a swim). AND, on top of that you have jettisoned 5 falcon upper stages and 5 trunks (compared to 1 External Tank for the shuttle flight). AND you have had 5 times the launch/range overheads and potentials for issues (the more times you fly, the more chance of failure no matter how good the machine)

Yes the shuttle was way more expensive and complex probably to refurbish. But the difference is not as large as you think when you look at the capacity capabilities of both system required to reach a given goal.

It's mostly caused by the compression of air molecules ahead of the spacecraft as it barrels through them at such ludicrous speeds. The air doesn't have time to get out of the way like it does around the wing of an airplane, so it kind of gathers up in front of the spacecraft. With pretty much any substance you can bet that the tighter you pack it together, the warmer it's going to get.

I do suspect SpaceX will get closer and closer to "reuse" (in the sense a commercial airline airplane is "reuse").  Don't forget that inspect and minor refurbish systems can also be automated to a greater and greater degree as time passes, which also implies "reuse" will gradually become closer to realized.  Plus, tiny cheap sensors can be inserted into materials now, then read out after each mission by software and thus more and more structural characteristics can be verified cheaply by software.  Without a doubt some systems will always need to be inspected and tested by humans, but that will become less and less necessary as time passes.  BTW, as a pilot, you should know that any pilot... even including "lame" pilots of tiny 2-seat private aircraft like me... checks 2, 3, 5 dozen things before every flight.  And this is for a typical "reuse" system (an airplane), not a "refurbish" system.  The truth is, once perfected (which takes quite a bit of effort), automated systems are vastly better for most purposes.  The reason is, they can actually detect and report weaknesses before they become "broken" or "not working"... while most tests performed by humans only detect components that are broken or seriously out of whack.

OK how about we do this another way.   Use less intensively inspected/refurbished launchers for payload only and a specialized space plane to hoist 3-4 crew for a rendezvous with a station or ship.   This would bring the cost down massively.   The space plane gets off the ground using A B-1 BOMBER!  Yup that's right the Lancer.   Now the bomber will have to be modified to go (back) to its top speed of Mach 2.3, reposition it's rear landing gear into the aft bomb bay, possibly lengthen it's landing gear, lose all its ECM hardware, add a spaceplane carry rack, add solid rocket boosters outboard of the main engines and also add reaction control systems so the boosters can get the carrier ship to mach 4 and 120,000 ft to launch it's spaceplane.   This space plane can be thought of as a super X-15 with a huge solid rocket booster.   The Lancer boosters will weigh in at 30,000 lbs, the spaceplane booster will be around 120,000 lbs and the spaceplane at about 50,000 lbs.  How will the modified Lancer get 200,000 lbs off the ground?  Easy,  drastically reduced fuel load.   This Lancer does not need to have a range of 5,100 miles.   About 500-700 miles will do.  The Lancer can carry 115,000 lbs of payload already,  the other 85,000 lbs will be reduced fuel.   I do see problems with the carrier heating up during its "reentry" and with recovering the SRB of the space plane,  bit this set-up should not be all that expensive to reuse and possibly partially refurbish for subsequent missions.   The B-1 itself costs about 75k dollars an hour to run.  The booster for the spaceplane/orbiter is recovered in 1 piece.  I'm thinking it can be launched for roughly 2.4 million dollars to get 3 people into orbit.

I think it's a real apples-to-oranges comparison here. Clearly you're trying to portray SpaceX's stuff in the best light, which is fine, but I think it's a bit disingenuous to compare the spacecraft and the booster on the shuttle's side (not to mention the shuttle's USAF requirements which made it so unwieldy, such as large wings and a large payload bay) to just SpaceX's booster. The design decisions SpaceX has made were available to NASA in the 70s, but they couldn't get funding to complete the thing without getting help from the USAF, which required the significant design compromises. I still feel pretty strongly that the systems required to recover the Falcon boosters outweigh (literally) the single-use rockets. Just like NASA failed to deliver on its promises of super-cheap spaceflight, I'm not remotely confident that SpaceX will be able to "revolutionize" space flight by recovering the boosters.

Also, it's not like physics is different for SpaceX. I think it's the height of arrogance to say you're going to do rocket science better than literally rocket scientists who've been at this for a half century.

Great video as usual. A few comments. SpaceX will have to slow things down once they start flying humans. They will kill some Astronauts at some point. It's not a matter of if but when. Spaceflight is hard and human spaceflight is very dangerous. The Shuttle and the Falcon 9 were designed for very different missions. The typical Shuttle payload capacity was about 50,045 pounds (22,700 kg) but could be increased depending on the choice of the launch configuration. It's a little harder to quantify the payload capacity of the Falcon 9 because there are so many versions and mission profiles. Here is WIKI's take on Falcon 9 payload. The current "Full Thrust" version can lift payloads of up to 22,800 kilograms (50,300 lb) to low Earth orbit, and up to 8,300 kg (18,300 lb) to geostationary transfer orbit (GTO), when flying in expendable mode. The first stage can be recovered and reused for GTO payloads up to 5,500 kg (12,100 lb) automatically landing after disconnection of the second stage. The Falcon 9 has been subsequently upgraded and uprated; on July 22, 2018 a Falcon 9 launched the Telstar 19V 7,075 kg (15,598 lb) satellite into a sub-synchronous transfer orbit, also called a GTO-orbit. At first glance it appears that the Shuttle and the Falcon 9 have very compareable payload capacity. If you are basing this purely on mass then they are compareable. However, they don't compare equally when looking at volume. As you pointed out in your video the Shuttle has capabilty that the Falcon 9 can't match. For instance, transporting something the size of Hubble and most of the ISS modules. The 2 systems have/had different mission profiles. Having been born in 1960 I watched the moon landings and remember how exciting space was back then. My father worked for NASA from 1958 until 1978 and then worked for NASA contractor Teledyne Brown on the Space Shuttle for another 15 years. We watched the first successful Falcon 9 landing together and it was neat to see him crack a smile after the booster safely landed. SpaceX is pushing that feeling of excitement once again. I am hopefull that SpaceX can push the technology to a point where rockets and spaceflight become as common place as a large passenger airliner flying across the country.

None of the Shuttle boosters were ever reflown. They were neither reusable nor refurbishable.

They were broken down into components, then a NEW booster (complete with a new serial number) was reassembled out of a mix of refurbished and new components. Some components flew on many of different boosters.

But all the work required to do this made recovering and refurbishing the components no cheaper than simply making new ones.

It definitely is more re-usable. SpaceX did a great job of nixing consumables and avoiding tear-downs. I think there are 3 main things that drastically separate the Falcons. 1. Separating the orbital re-entry vehicle/crew capsule from the launch propulsion systems. Orbital crew vehicles will always take much more time to properly inspect than a suborbital stages. Those Dragon capsules/human variants will not be turned around in 24 hrs ever. 2. Avoiding SRB's altogether eliminates a massive consumable: refilling big tanks of stable cryogenics vs repacking a massive rocket with tons of explosives. 3. The most impressive thing was getting the Merlin's reliable enough for simple inspections rather than tear downs, but I suppose 50 years of advancement in tech, controls, and materials will do that. SSME was great for its time, but just like in cars, a decent recent design is better than the best from half a century ago.

1. As you hinted the SRB is actually not a component that can actually be reusable. One fact you skipped is that the nozzle of a solid rocket booster is not reusable as you have no cryogenic or liquid propellant to cool it, so it uses ablative cooling or no cooling at all. And a solid Rocket can not be relit or throttled. And as a side note, a single SRB has nearly 30 times more more thrust at sea-level than a Merlin 1C Engine.
2. The level of work hours refurbishing a space shuttle is more comparable to a full overhaul of a jet airliner.
3. The Space Shuttle Main Engine (SSME) is not really comparable to a Merlin Engine. (I think one NASA engineer called the SSME the Ferrari of rocket engines. The SSME is build to be efficient through a wide variety of heights, because it travels with the orbiter, while the Falcon 9 can use 2 different engine bells throughout the flight. And last but not least. The SSME has between 4 and 5 times more thrust than a Merlin (1C)Engine, which makes the Space Shuttle at least as strong as 12 Merlin (1C) Engines.

Your video was great. Very informative. One criticism though: Toward the end you commented that the Space Shuttle had “very minimal” upgrades over its 30+ year lifespan. That is not correct. Several major upgrades occurred. The ET was totally redesigned early on to save weight. It went from aluminum to an aluminum-lithium alloy that shaved nearly 8000 kg from its original weight. The SRBs and Main engines also went through upgrades to increase performance and payload to orbit. Those improvements and the weight savings of the ET and other components boosted the payload to orbit by about 7250 kg. a 35% increase in capacity!!
And, the most visible upgrade was the avionics and “glass-cockpit” upgrade that occurred starting in 1999. The orbiters got the glass cockpit plus new avionics, hydraulics and flight computers.
So… some significant improvements did occur. But the amount of safety checks also increased significantly, making the originally planned 26 flight/year goal impossible. If the flight rate had gotten anywhere near that rate, I’m sure the cost per flight would have been much lower, although it could never have achieved its “advertised” goal of $1400/kg to orbit.

Fun thing about shipping costs is they're also something that historically was extremely expensive.
(though probably not on the scale of a rocket launch, even relatively speaking)

Shipping something overland was slow, risky, and very expensive.
Shipping it by water was a lot cheaper, but the costs of loading and unloading ships were very high, and very labour intensive.

So... What changed, in the modern world, besides technology in general?
Shipping containers.

Seems innocent enough, but that one thing reduced the costs of transporting goods by something like a factor of 100.

And it's not like you'd need modern technology for that concept. Sure stuff like cranes and steel and the like help a lot, but broadly speaking the idea behind a shipping container would've been possible 1-2000 years ago. Just... Nobody thought about it, or considered why you'd want to do that.

The challenges with rocket launches that make them so expensive are quite different of course, but it's just a random example showing how something seemingly insignificant can have such a huge impact...

SpaceX's biggest financial challenge is their own ambition. Right now, they have substantial F9/FH R&D costs to recover, but they are also far ahead of their competitors and have a majority market share, so they could quickly turn profit through satellites launches and sustain this for many years to come. However, almost all that revenue is going into R&D for their Mars colonization vehicle, and, while doubling the number of planets our economy covers is obviously financially promising in the ultra-long term, it's difficult to see medium-long term profits coming out of this. Further, they are almost exclusively focused on the vehicle, and little on the colony, so this really needs wide partnership, or substantial growth to go anywhere sustainable. Maybe Starlink or Earth-to-Earth gets them the funding they need, but these ideas can not be relied upon to come to fruition, and are each R&D burdens themselves. It's all very exciting, but I just hope they will build up a significant bank balance to shield themselves from unexpected downturns and protect what they've already achieved.

At about 6:15 "begins to build up a ton of friction and therefore a ton of heat" ... it is my understanding that friction has nothing to do with it. It is compression of the atmosphere ahead of the orbiter. Think Diesel engine. When you compress air, it gets hot. Compress it a lot, it gets really hot. A deorbiting spaceship using aerobraking compresses the air ahead of it ... a lot. Otherwise a great video - as usual!

6:18 "and starts to build up a ton of friction"--would like to point out that because air density and boundary layer mechanics of compressible flow, a very large majority of reentry heat is compressive heating of the atmosphere by the spacecraft in front of it, not friction of the spacecraft against the atmosphere. I personally don't think the comparison is valid at all (I liked the video anyway):
1) The Falcon 9 only reuses the first stage so it's technically not a reusable rocket, but a reusable first stage.
2) The Space Shuttle was a manned system and always carried people to LEO; no (reused) Falcon 9 has flown
people yet, let alone a many as the STS.
3) The STS orbiter was an LEO vehicle and unlike the Falcon 9 first stage booster returned from orbit, not from
a ballistic sub-orbital trajectory. (I know, you mentioned that, but still)
4) Fast turnaround for manned space flight operation of the Falcon 9 (if implemented at all, which I doubt
as the focus is on the BFR/BFS) will only be done until the first accident...
5) As you pointed out, the STS SRB is a completely different beast from a liquid rocket booster and thus
refurbishment is the only practical option for such system anyway...
6) A reasonable comparison would be between the BFR/BF-combo and the STS, which isn't possible yet :/

I guess the next question is how BFS will manage reentry without the problems the Shuttle had, much less going an additional 50% faster coming in hot from mars (thus 3x the heat). I'd assume a huge win would be a single piece heatshield rather than tiles. Cutting NASA out of the loop would almost certainly help too. I mean, they don't tear down a commercial airline after every flight to inspect every part, and if the shuttle was really so flawed as to need this, why didn't anyone try to improve it? The problem with design freezes is that it sets every problem in the system, known or otherwise, in stone. They knew the heat tiles were a big problem from pretty early on, certainly after STS-27 in 1988 when Atlantis very nearly suffered the same fate that later claimed Columbia, but the design was nevertheless frozen for "safety" or "costs" or something and it ended up in tragedy. Even assuming no one had a better idea for a reusable heatshield than the tiles, once the cost in labour of inspecting and repairing the tiles was clear, wouldn't it have been safer AND cheaper to switch to a simple single piece ablative heat shield and just replace it as a unit after every few flights? But then, NASA had their hands tied by Congress, who of course knew better.

Anyway, rant over. How does SpaceX intend to avoid the non-heatshield shortcomings of the shuttle that made the shuttle so expensive with BFS?

Couple of points:

The Shuttle lifted a crew to orbit from its very first flight. NASA now wants SpaceX to fly a booster of identical design seven times before "man-rated" is conferred. It's not helping that SpaceX is in the habit of tweaking their booster after every flight.

The heat tiles on the belly of the Shuttle were each different. If one or more of those tiles were found to be damaged and needed to be replaced they had to be crafted to order. They differed enough in thickness and contour that they couldn't use generic tiles. They were amazing, at the time they showed off how you could hold a tile with your bare hands while the other end was blow-torched, red-hot and would just cool off.

Back in my comp.sci. studies the Shuttle avionics software was touted as the one and only software project that followed strict feedback loops of quality control. The Airbus avionics software came close too. They absolutely, positively wanted no software bugs making it into space. Compare that to Windows 10 that's so buggy that Microsoft considers its user base to be Beta-testers.

The Dragon is a reusable spacecraft ... and they have sent flight-proven dragons to the ISS.  It also returns from orbit -- at orbital speed.  SpaceX is using the dragon to learn about orbital craft re-usability.  No mention of the dragon in this video seems like an odd omission.

Before the space shuttle was tasked with National Reconnaissance missions requiring its huge (Hubble Space Telescope size) payload bay, it was a smaller vehicle and one proposal would have had three "lifting body" type  re-useable, piloted space planes joined in a  three sided configuration where two of them would help the third one get to where the atmospheric drag would be low enough to get to orbit by itself. Other proposals would have the boosters be piloted with Rogallo parafoil type lifting surfaces and landing gear deployed for landings. That increase in capacity became the straw that nearly broke the camels back, or put another way, turned what could have been a 'race horse' into a 'camel', the definition of  what a race horse would become if it had been designed by a committee.

"Is re-usability actually upon us"? How many of SpaceX's launches in the last year were 'flight proven' boosters? There's your answer. Interestingly, the first reuse carries the highest cost savings (up to nearly half the price) whereas the second reuse only moves it from 1/2 to 1/3 (theoretical).
